text: css grid is a fine way to style anything. you may run into some difficulty with IE though as the prefixed version works a little differently
take it for me.  be careful.  IE will bite you hard.
all these cool things that you will discover with grid and then implement.
then you will look at ie…
and scream
Make it in flexbox.
Then use @supports to rewrite it in grid and make it exactly how you want it.
pro tip: don’t use `and` or `or` in your supports query, HubSpot’s Minifier bombs when it sees that.
You can use grid in IE, you just have to implement everything using the underlying mathematics instead of using nice things like `grid-template-area`.
And you have to use the MS-specific property names. That’s not entirely bad, though, because that allows you to only apply those styles in a MS browser.

Howdy dev friends!

The open source HubL VS Code language extension I started is up in the marketplace!
<https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=WilliamSpiro.hubl#overview>
<https://cdn2.HubSpot.net/hubfs/2359872/IMPORTANT/DONOTDELETE/hubl-language-extension/nifty_gif.gif>

This extension enables super fast local development of CMS pages, and is a great compliment to using the new local HubL server (<https://designers.HubSpot.com/docs/tools/local-hubl-server-hubdb-beta?hs_preview=BCdZzrti-6716108127>). It contains comprehensive HubL tag, function, filter and expression test auto-complete snippets, as well as their documentation. There is some additional helpful HubL things like for loop and all of the content.<something> snippets - it is all documented here: <https://github.com/williamspiro/HubL-Language-Extension>

*This is for all of us developers, so please file issues, fork, star, PR the thing!*

HubL functions and tags are access by typing a `~` prefix, filters are accessed by typing a `|` prefix, and expression tests/other helpful things just are typed in. You will see auto-complete suggestions and documentation pop up, like this:
<https://cdn2.HubSpot.net/hubfs/2359872/IMPORTANT/DONOTDELETE/hubl-language-extension/params.png>

You enter/tab complete snippets, and then can tab through the snippet variables to fill in

This is also super helpful for HubL syntax highlighting <https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=wholroyd.jinja>
i believe autoprefixer recently added some hot sauce for `grid-template-areas`
they did. It works for 80%/90% of grid stuff. I’ve still had to tweak further but it’s better than nothing

Hi everyone! :wave: We're thinking about expanding the abilities of global groups. With those changes, we would allow pre-built sections to have different levels of edit-ability:

1. A global and completely non-editable section (basically a global group today)
2. A global section whose content is editable
3. A global section whose content and layout it editable
4. A local section whose content is editable
5. A local section whose content and layout is editable

/poll "Which one(s) would you be likely to use?" "A global and completely non-editable section (basically a global group today)" "A global section whose content is editable" "A global section whose content and layout it editable" "A local section whose content is editable" "A local section whose content and layout is editable"

I've used TorGuard in the past and it worked mostly well, although I think these VPN services constantly have to spin up new IPs and servers because Cloudflare and other providers constantly block them because of nefarious users that all share the same IP.

If you need something more stable and long-term, now I just create my own VPN by spinning up an AWS instance with OpenVPN server and using the OpenVPN client on my computer. It's pretty easy to setup. You'll be limited by the availability regions of AWS (or whatever provider you use), but AWS has at least a couple dozen different regions/countries available.
If you selected an option in the poll above, can you tell us a little more about how you'd want to use that option?
Thread: A global and completely non-editable section (basically a global group today)
Thread: A global section whose content is editable
Thread: A global section whose content and layout it editable
Thread: A local section whose content is editable
Thread: A local section whose content and layout is editable

what about almost all of them? xD
Where should I start the thread for that?
That works too! :smile:
Would you use the different options for different things?
First of all, I think we should have the ability to grant those permissions to each global module independently.
thats why I voted 2-5
Would you want all of those options to be edited on the page level? Only in the Design Manager? Both?

yes definitely.
I can see granting permissions to the global group header:
- Content editable (so nobody can mess up the layout easily, but can change the global menu of the website without access the DM).
- Local editable (so they can easily create a local one for example for a thank you page where they want to insert an specific menu)
for any other GM that is used across the website its similar logic but expanding to the layout too

the permissions? I think that should be managed only on the DM. So whenever you use the GM the permissions are the same.
But having the local section clone doesn't mean it will be automatically converted to that right?
Just if you click in a boolean to actually activate that
Gotcha
My brains too tired to think through this so I’m just gonna say whatever <@U7ADCU3BM> says is probably exactly my thoughts as well

Does anyone in here have a suggested platform for a "customer portal" that would integrate with the CRM? Basically need an app that allows customers to log in with username/password credentials and see different documents or other engagements/objects associated with their account. Or is this something that could be done in the service hub? Just curious.

^ would also love to hear what other people have used. Trying to make a website that is an educational hub for customers, but don't want to build it on HubSpot since it will require user authenitication and management
You could use content membership for this
Doesn't that only work for enterprise?
And pull in contact properties and crm objects on the authorized pages
Yes only enterprise
I’ve built stuff like this on HS, without the memberships feature - it’s a lot of crazy work though that is borderline “hacky” I’d use the content memberships feature they’re testing right now
